title: 107_s1720
content:
The "Victims of Anthrax Tax Relief Act of 2001" includes provisions for income and employment taxes of victims of terrorist attacks, estate tax reduction, charitable organization payments, exclusion of certain cancellations of indebtedness, and no impact on social security trust funds. The "Victims of Anthrax Tax Relief Act of 2001" amends Section 692 to provide tax exemptions for individuals who die as a result of anthrax attacks between September 11, 2001, and January 1, 2002. The "Victims of Anthrax Tax Relief Act of 2001" exempts certain benefits from taxation for individuals who die due to anthrax attacks between September 11, 2001, and January 1, 2002. Exceptions apply to amounts payable in the taxable year by reason of the death of an individual described in the Act. The "Victims of Anthrax Tax Relief Act of 2001" exempts certain benefits from taxation for individuals who die due to anthrax attacks between September 11, 2001, and January 1, 2002. The Act also allows for refunds of other taxes paid by individuals affected by the attacks. The "Victims of Anthrax Tax Relief Act of 2001" increases the amount of taxes imposed on individuals affected by anthrax attacks. Conforming and clerical amendments are made to sections related to victims of certain terrorist attacks. The section amends income and employment taxes for members of the Armed Forces and victims of terrorist attacks on death. It also reduces estate taxes for combat zone-related deaths and victims of terrorist attacks. Effective from taxable years ending on or after September 11, 2001. The section applies a reduced estate tax rate for qualified decedents who died in combat zones while serving in the Armed Forces of the United States. The section provides a reduced estate tax rate for qualified decedents who died in combat zones while serving in the Armed Forces of the United States or as a result of a terrorist attack involving anthrax between September 11, 2001, and January 1, 2002. The rate schedule is specified in the legislation. The tentative tax rates are as follows:
- Not over $150,000: 1% of the amount exceeding $100,000
- Over $150,000 but not over $200,000: $500 plus 2% of the excess over $150,000
- Over $200,000 but not over $300,000: $1,500 plus 3% of the excess over $200,000
- Over $300,000 but not over $500,000: $4,500 plus 4% of the excess over $300,000
- Over $500,000 but not over $700,000: (rate not specified) For incomes over $500,000 but not over $700,000, the tax is $12,500 plus 5% of the excess. For incomes over $700,000 but not over $900,000, the tax is $22,500 plus 6% of the excess. For incomes over $900,000 but not over $1,100,000, the tax is $34,500 plus 7% of the excess. For incomes over $1,100,000 but not over $1,600,000, the tax is $48,500 plus 8% of the excess. For incomes over $1,600,000 but not over $2,100,000, the tax is $88,500 plus 9% of the excess. For incomes over $2,100,000 but not over $2,600,000, the tax is $133,500 plus 10% of the excess. For incomes over $2,600,000 but not over $3,100,000, the tax is $183,500 plus 11% of the excess. For incomes over $3,100,000 but not over $3,600,000, the tax is $238,500 plus 12% of the excess. For incomes over $3,600,000 but not over $4,100,000, the tax is $298,500 plus 13% of the excess. For incomes over $4,100,000 but not over $5,100,000, the tax is $363,500 plus 14% of the excess. For incomes over $5,100,000, the tax is $503,500 plus 15% of the excess. For higher incomes, the tax rates increase progressively with each bracket. The tax rates for estates over $9,100,000 are $1,163,500 plus 19% of the excess, and for estates over $10,100,000, it is $1,353,500 plus 20% of the excess. Amendments are made to sections 2011 and 2053(d)(3)(B) in relation to estate taxes. Amendments are made to sections 2011 and 2053(d)(3)(B) in relation to estate taxes, including the repeal of paragraph (9) of section 532(c) of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the item relating to section 2201 in the table of sections for subchapter C of chapter 11. Sec. 2201 addresses combat zone-related deaths of Armed Forces members and victims of certain terrorist attacks. The amendments apply to estates of decedents dying on or after September 11, 2001. Additionally, Section 4 discusses payments by charitable organizations treated as exempt payments. Payments made by a 501(c)(3) organization due to anthrax-related terrorist attacks between September 11, 2001, and January 1, 2002, will be considered related to the organization's purpose if made using a consistent formula. Private foundations can make such payments without being penalized under section 4941 of the Internal Revenue Code. Effective September 11, 2001, payments made by 501(c)(3) organizations related to anthrax-related terrorist attacks are exempt from penalties under section 4941 of the Internal Revenue Code. SEC. 5. EXCLUSION OF CERTAIN CANCELLATIONS OF INDEBTEDNESS. Gross income excludes discharged indebtedness due to death from a terrorist attack involving anthrax between Sept 11, 2001, and Jan 1, 2002. Return requirements under section 6050P do not apply. Effective for discharges from Sept 11, 2001, to Jan 1, 2002. SEC. 6. NO IMPACT ON SOCIAL SECURITY TRUST FUND. The Act does not affect title II of the Social Security Act or its regulations. The Secretary of the Treasury must estimate the impact of the Act on the trust funds under section 201 of the Social Security Act. If there is a negative impact, funds will be transferred from general revenues. The Act ensures that trust fund income and balances are maintained by transferring funds less frequently than quarterly from the Federal Government's general revenues.
